description: Chemistry in the vacuum of space.

slides.title: What is Astrochemistry?
slides.content:
# Space Lab üß™

The study of abundance and reactions of molecules in the Universe, and their interaction with radiation.

It connects Astronomy and Chemistry.

slides.title: The Interstellar Medium (ISM)
slides.content:
# The Stuff Between üåå

Space isn't completely empty.
- 99% Gas (Hydrogen, Helium).
- 1% Dust (Silicates, Carbon).
- Density is incredibly low (1 atom per $cm^3$ vs $10^{19}$ in air).

slides.title: Molecular Clouds
slides.content:
# Stellar Nurseries üçº

Cold, dense clouds where complex molecules can survive.
- Shielded from UV radiation by dust.
- Site of star formation.
- Home to Water, Ammonia, Alcohol, etc.

slides.title: Spectroscopy
slides.content:
# Fingerprints of Light üåà

How we know what's out there.
- Molecules absorb/emit specific frequencies.
- **Radio Telescopes** (ALMA) detect rotational transitions of cold molecules.

slides.title: Detection Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which tool is primarily used to identify molecules in cold dark clouds?

slides.title: Chemistry on Dust Grains
slides.content:
# The Meeting Place ü§ù

Gas atoms in space rarely meet.
- **Dust grains** act as a surface (catalyst).
- Atoms stick, meet partners, react ($H + H \to H_2$), and release.

slides.title: Complex Organic Molecules
slides.content:
# Prebiotic Soup üçú

We've found:
- Methanol ($CH_3OH$)
- Ethanol (Alcohol)
- Amino Acid precursors
- Sugars (Glycolaldehyde)

Building blocks of life exist in space!

slides.title: PAHs
slides.content:
# Soot of Stars üè≠

Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons.
- Chicken-wire sheets of Carbon.
- Very stable.
- Contain ~20% of galactic carbon.
- Often glow in Infrared.

slides.title: Cosmic Rays
slides.content:
# High Energy Drivers ‚ö°

High-speed protons hitting molecules.
- Drive chemistry in cold dark places (Ionization).
- Can destroy molecules or provide energy to build them.

slides.title: Cometary Chemistry
slides.content:
# Frozen Time Capsules üßä

Comets preserve the chemistry of the early solar system.
- Rosetta mission landed on Comet 67P.
- Found organics and water (though different isotope ratio than Earth).

slides.title: Titan's Atmosphere
slides.content:
# Orange Haze üü†

Saturn's Moon Titan.
- Orange smog of Tholins (complex organics created by Sunlight + Methane + Nitrogen).
- Like early Earth before life?

slides.title: Panspermia
slides.content:
# Life from Space? ‚òÑÔ∏è

Hypothesis: Life (or its ingredients) arrived on Earth via comets/meteorites.
- We find amino acids in meteorites (Murchison meteorite).
- Plausible origin story.

slides.title: Water in Universe
slides.content:
# Ubiquitous H2O üíß

Water is everywhere.
- Ice on grains.
- Vapor in hot stars.
- Liquid on planets.
- Third most common molecule (after $H_2$ and $CO$).

slides.title: Origin Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: The theory that life's ingredients came from space rocks is called:

slides.title: Cool Stars
slides.content:
# Molecular Atmospheres üî¥

Red Giants and Brown Dwarfs are cool enough to have molecules in their 'air'.
- Titanium Oxide ($TiO$).
- Water vapor.
- Methane.

slides.title: Isotopes
slides.content:
# Chemical Clues üïµÔ∏è

Different number of neutrons ($H$ vs Deuterium).
- Ratio tells us temperature/origin.
- Earth's water D/H ratio matches asteroids better than comets.

slides.title: Formation of Planets
slides.content:
# Chemical Sorting üå™Ô∏è

- **Snow Line**: Distance from sun where ice stays solid.
- Inside Line: Rocks/Metals (Earth).
- Outside Line: Ices/Gas (Jupiter).
Chemistry dictated planet types.

slides.title: Exoplanet Atmospheres
slides.content:
# Sniffing Worlds üëÉ

When a planet passes Sun, light filters through air.
- JWST telescope detects Water, $CO_2$, Methane.
- Searching for **Biosignatures** (Oxygen + Methane together).

slides.title: Astrochem Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **Spectroscopy** is our tool.
- **Dust** is the factory.
- Space is full of organic molecules.
- Chemistry builds the stage for biology.
